body: THE black awning, which stretches like a tidy gold-lettered baseball cap over the store at the corner of Washington Avenue and Prospect Place in Brooklyn, reads ''F.B. Enterprises.'' Passers-by curious about what might lie within would have to come close and examine the small hand-lettered sign bearing the words ''Post Office'' that is taped to the
title: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; You've Got Mail. And That's Just for Starters.

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: AFTER their marriage four years ago, Amy Yang and Don Kim did what they were supposed to do. They saved to buy a home. ''As newlyweds coming from a traditional working-class background, you kind of move with the ladder,'' Ms. Yang said. ''You get married, think about buying something, think about kids -- the chain of events in life.'' The two met
title: THE HUNT; All in the Family, and Then Some

body: Arkadiy Shats was gentle, examining the old patient and deciding he had no choice but to operate. The surgery went fast: no more than 10 seconds of juggling a screwdriver and a pair of tweezers. The patient was a pager. Remember pagers? They were the razzle-dazzle innovation that kept doctors tethered to patients, drug dealers tethered to
title: To Send a Page, Press #, Then Hope It Still Works

body: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the most popular tax break for apartment building developers, adopting a plan intended to induce them to build tens of thousands of apartments for people other than the well-heeled. The changes, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg supported and which would go into effect in 2008,
title: IN OVERHAUL, CITY SEEKS TO EXPAND LOWER-COST UNITS

Tomorrow, 5 to 8:30 p.m., candlelight tours, with demonstrations of holiday customs from the 17th to the 19th centuries, including a Wassail reception, $27.50; members, $22. Reservations required: (718) 351-1611, Ext. 281.

body: It was the first of three public hearings on the $4.2 billion Atlantic Yards development, and Umar Jordan, a 51-year-old resident of Bushwick, Brooklyn, strode to the front of the auditorium and offered a vigorous defense of the proposal. ''I'm here to speak for the underprivileged, the people that don't get the opportunity to work, the brothers
title: Perspectives on the Atlantic Yards Development Through the Prism of Race

body: A 67-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with fatally shooting a man in Prospect Heights, the police said. The two men were arguing around 1 p.m. at 583 Vanderbilt Avenue when the gunman, Clement Calixte, shot the other man once in the back, the police said. The victim, whom the police did not identify, was taken to New York
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Accused Of Murder

body: To the Editor: In ''On the Block'' (Oct. 22), about the Atlantic Yards plan in Brooklyn, all the Fort Greene residents you interviewed were against it and all the Crown Heights residents were for it. It is easy to be in favor of a project that is more than a mile from your home, is a convenient destination for shoppers or basketball fans, and is
title: Atlantic Yards Plan: Be Afraid. Very Afraid.

body: NOT since the Dodgers departed in 1957 has there been a slugfest in Brooklyn like the one over Atlantic Yards. The plan is colossal -- 16 high-rise buildings and an 18,000-seat basketball arena on 22 acres near the borough's busy downtown -- and fans and opponents have matched its magnitude with their own statistics. The developer, Forest City
title: On the Block

body: WHEN the New York Mets completed a nifty three-game sweep of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the first round of the playoffs eight days ago, the city's streets took on a certain glow, as thousands of long-suffering Met fans like me went around town with heads as giant and transfigured by joy as that of Mr. Met himself. But for many of the city's most
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Ticket Thicket

body: The National Fair Housing Alliance, a consortium of 220 groups and individuals working against housing discrimination, charged yesterday that agents in the Brooklyn Heights office of the city's largest residential real estate brokerage, the Corcoran Group, had engaged in discriminatory sales practices, including racial steering and withholding
title: Report Alleges Bias by a Real Estate Giant

body: A man crossing Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill about 3:50 a.m. yesterday was struck by two vehicles and killed, the police said. The driver of the first vehicle, Dion Gadsen, 26, of Prospect Heights, was charged with driving with a suspended license, and the driver of the second vehicle was not charged, the police said. The identity of the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies After Being Struck By Two Cars

body: A 22-year-old man was killed when he fell off a roof during a party in Prospect Heights early yesterday morning, the police said. The man, identified as Alexander Vaubel of Carroll Gardens, was trying to move from a roof at 460 Prospect Place to 462 Prospect Place when he fell into an alley between the buildings shortly after 2 a.m., the police
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies In Fall From Roof

body: AROUND 15 years ago, a decade after Sean Sweeney got out of the party-planning business and moved into a loft in the artists' haven and former industrial backwater called SoHo, he found himself the host of a meeting of a neighborhood group called the SoHo Alliance. The group's answering service, it turned out, had a severe backlog of unreturned
title: The Mini Mayors

body: On the final day for public comment on the state's draft environmental review of the Atlantic Yards project, a coalition of Brooklyn neighborhood associations, churches and businesses will today be the latest to sharply criticize the review. The criticisms are in a report that asks why the environmental review provided no evidence for its assertion
title: More Find Fault With Atlantic Yards Review

body: A group of neighborhood and civic associations will propose a series of changes to Brooklyn's controversial Atlantic Yards real estate development this weekend, taking a new tack in the bitter debate over the project. The effort will diverge markedly from the strategy of other project skeptics, notably Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, a coalition of
title: Brooklyn Group to Propose Changes to Yards Project

body: Joyce Quitasol tried a number of careers, including art restoration and forensic psychology, before following in the footsteps of her grandmother by going into baking. Now she and her husband, Mo Chin, a photographer, have opened Joyce Bakeshop in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, joining a number of good new bakeries in that borough. Miniature iced
title: FOOD STUFF; Cupcakes and Tartlets Cavort With Croissants

body: For the four Democrats running for Congress in central Brooklyn, there may be differing views on a host of subjects. But on one topic there is strong agreement: They all contend that the United States' military involvement in Iraq is a bad thing and that the troops should be pulled out as soon as possible. All the candidates contend that the war is
title: Who Is Most Opposed to Iraq War? Four Congressional Candidates Make It a Brooklyn Battle

body: For nearly 25 years, Roger L. Green has represented a swath of central Brooklyn in the Assembly, but now that he is running for Congress, the race to succeed him has become one of the most contentious in New York City. The three candidates running in the Democratic primary for the seat, representing the 57th Assembly District, each have political
title: In Brooklyn, a Fierce Contest to Be Assembly Successor

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: THE overpowering smell of vanilla in her home led Priscilla Maddox to her current business -- and passion. In 2000, Ms. Maddox was 16 years into retirement, after 36 years of employment in New York City hospitals and at a nursing home, when she decided to try turning her cookie-making skills into a business. For two weeks, she supplied batch after
title: HOME FRONT; Can't Stand the Heat? Then Rent the Kitchen

body: Ken Diamondstone, a small developer in Brooklyn, deserves a lot of credit. He's running against State Senator Marty Conner, a long-term incumbent who also happens to be a lawyer specializing in election law. Mr. Conner has long been the go-to man for politicians who want to get pesky challengers off the ballot. Naturally, Mr. Diamondstone faced
title: Endorsements and Complaints

body: To the Editor: It may be ''getting easier'' to find so-called green buildings in New York, but then again, because we tend to live close together in small apartments and drive less than average (if at all), New Yorkers have always used far less energy than the average American. Steven O'Neill Prospect Heights, Brooklyn
title: New Yorkers Conserve

body: FOR 40 years, people made the pilgrimage from across the city to Christie's Jamaican Patties, on the northwest corner of Sterling Place and Flatbush Avenue, for savory pastries stuffed with spicy beef and chicken. A line of customers often trailed out the door of the shabby-looking shop, which sat on a cheese-shaped wedge on the end of the block.
title: Street Level/North Flatbush Avenue; On a Mom-and-Pop Block, the Big Boys Arrive

body: Of all the real estate jargon, bureaucratic buzzwords and plain old insults exchanged over the proposed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, no term has evoked quite such unruly passion as ''blighted.'' During the last two years, the word has hung like a scythe over the 22-acre site, most of it on the northern edge of the Prospect Heights
title: Blight, Like Beauty, Can Be in the Eye Of the Beholder

body: THE tables at the new Christie's aren't used much yet. Most customers dash in for a patty to go, maybe because they never saw a table at the old quarters of this 40-year-old Prospect Heights stalwart, which recently moved half a block closer to Prospect Park on Flatbush Avenue. The Jamaican patties -- beef and otherwise -- are hefty but not
title: $25 AND UNDER; To Grab and Run, or to Linger Over

body: WHEN 39-year-old Anthony Sisto was growing up in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, the older kids on the block warned him never to set foot in neighboring Sunset Park. It was just too dangerous. But Mr. Sisto grew up, and Brooklyn changed. Now Mr. Sisto lives happily in the formerly off-limits neighborhood with his wife, Meggan Cole-Sisto, who seems at
title: HABITATS/Sunset Park; Learning To Bypass The Roadblocks

body: THE four-story warehouse at 603 West 29th Street doesn't look like much. A set of beat-up metal gates permanently shutter the truck bays, and a couple of faded yellow signs reading ABA Beverage Inc. are all that adorn this brick building on the northwestern edge of Chelsea. But several afternoons each week, the space in front of the building
title: URBAN TACTICS; Nabbing the Elusive Nickel

body: It will be months, if not years, before a single brick of the Atlantic Yards project is laid near Downtown Brooklyn. But as the fall election season draws near, the unbuilt, unapproved, multibillion-dollar development is shaping up as a major political issue in this corner of the borough. ''This is a litmus test for brownstone Brooklyn,'' said City
title: Atlantic Yards, Still but a Plan, Shapes Politics In Brooklyn

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: THE last straw for Stephanie Jo Klein came when the towers of boxes that cluttered her Kips Bay apartment -- which doubled as the office for her gift-bag business -- started tipping over. One day, a tissue packet from a pile of ''random girly things'' fell on her head. ''I thought: I do not want to live like this,'' she said. ''My apartment was so
title: THE HUNT; Enough Room for the Gift Bags

body: THEIR glue guns were cocked, their scissors sharpened, their beer glasses full. Nellie Kurtzman announced that the evening's theme would be ''horsepower.'' In a blustery tempest of shoeboxes, pipe cleaners and multicolored felt, they were off. So began the third installment of Diorama Lodge, an occasional event held in the dingy back room of
title: URBAN STUDIES/GLUE-GUNNING; Just Like Third Grade, but With a Chaser of Beer

body: IT'S all gone: every diamond ring, every stack of bills and birth certificate. Today, the safe deposit boxes in the subterranean vault of what used to be the Williamsburgh Savings Bank lie empty in haphazard piles on the dusty floor. The massive vault doors, several feet thick, stand open. No calls will ever go out to Mrs. Helen Massone, whose
title: For Brooklyn's Beacon, The Luxe Life

body: A picture caption last Sunday with the continuation of a cover article about the developer Bruce Ratner's projects misstated the site of his Atlantic Yards development. It is on rail yards and other land in Prospect Heights and on a block in Park Slope. It is not in Downtown Brooklyn, although it is near that neighborhood. In addition, three
title: Corrections

body: If Bruce Ratner's recent embrace of high-end architecture has some New Yorkers rolling their eyes, he can't be all that surprised. Not so long ago this developer's most visible cultural contribution to the city was a few kitschy theaters on 42nd Street. In Brooklyn he is known mainly as the creator of Metrotech, a complex of overblown yet banal
title: ARCHITECTURE; Skyline For Sale

body: TODAY is the 60th birthday of the celebrated Nigerian artist Obiora Udechukwu. Forget to send a card? Then at least plan a trip to see his new exhibition of pen-and-ink line drawings at the Skoto Gallery in Chelsea, which opened on Thursday and runs through July 20. Skoto is just one of many spots to take in the sights, sounds and smells of West
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: WEST AFRICAN ENCLAVES; Tastes of Nigeria, Sounds of Sierra Leone

body: IN a city where the price of a cashmere sweater has surpassed $1,000 in some quarters and summer utility bills may do the same, finding a one-bedroom rental apartment at that price seems pretty improbable. Or so you'd think. But a survey released earlier this year by New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development found that
title: What You Can Rent for

body: Fossils in the Walls Q. My children and I love fossils. Lately I've heard that there are some great-looking ones in Manhattan building walls and pillars. Can you recommend any buildings for fossil viewing? A. Sidney Horenstein, geologist and environmental educator emeritus at the American Museum of Natural History, recommended these: The
title: F. Y. I.

body: Time went backward -- and was knocked down violently -- last Christmas Day, when a car crashed into an old-fashioned street clock on Flatbush Avenue and Sterling Place in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. Within a few weeks, the Victorian-style timepiece and its cast-iron pole had been removed, arousing the concern of some neighborhood residents. One was
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; For a Victorian-Style Clock, a Hard-Knock Life

body: GRETA GILBERTSON was caught off guard recently when her 9-year-old daughter, who attends a private school on the Upper West Side, requested a cellphone. ''I sort of snapped at her,'' recalled Ms. Gilbertson, an assistant professor at Fordham University in the Bronx. ''I said, 'Don't think that you're one of the rich kids, because you're not.' ''
title: Money Changes Everything

body: Arsonists strike time and again for reasons all too familiar to the investigators who chase them. They set fires for profit, to satisfy a jealous rage, or to create danger so that they can then rush in and play the hero. And when they light their fires, they often leave clues -- in the charred wood left behind, or simply in the absence of other
title: In the Hottest of Crimes, Trails Are Often Cold

body: It isn't easy to create a real downtown district, vibrant and intense, in a city as sprawling and diffuse as Los Angeles, Frank Gehry admits. But that's what he has set out to do with his design for Grand Avenue, unveiled in preliminary form yesterday. The $750 million project, which includes the first high-rises he has ever designed for his
title: Imagining a Downtown For Vast Los Angeles

body: Hakeem Jeffries, a lawyer who has been active in Brooklyn civic activities, announced yesterday that he was running for the Assembly seat being vacated by Roger L. Green. Mr. Green is challenging the incumbent, Edolphus Towns, in a Democratic primary for the House of Representatives. This will be Mr. Jeffries's third campaign for the seat in the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Assembly Candidacy

body: WHEN it comes to making homes out of municipal buildings, New York developers have been very creative, fashioning luxury living spaces out of former factories, hospitals, police stations and banks. One of the most recent transformations is of a firehouse in Brooklyn. At 735 Dean Street, between Underhill and Vanderbilt Avenues in Prospect Heights,
title: POSTINGS; Firehouse Condos (Minus the Pole)

author: E-mail: sportsbiz@nytimes.com
body: The Nets can't leave the Meadowlands soon enough for what they believe will be the friendlier financial confines of downtown Brooklyn. The Nets are not dying at Continental Arena, as might have been expected for a team with one sneaker out the door. Attendance is averaging 16,784 a game, up 11.2 percent from last season. There have been a modest
title: SPORTS BUSINESS; Nets' Chances Look Good; Books Don't

body: When Bruce Ratner first announced plans to build Atlantic Yards, a vast residential, office and arena project on 22 acres near Downtown Brooklyn, perhaps the biggest practical obstacle he faced was the hundreds of people who already lived and worked there. Many protested, hung banners from windows and joined groups opposing the project. But others
title: Forced to Move, Some Find Greener Grass

body: SoHo Loft $3,200,000 MANHATTAN: 876 Broadway (at 19th Street) A four-bedroom, three-bath loft. Debra LaChance (212) 941-2643, and Erin Boisson Aries (212) 941-2568, the Corcoran Group; www.corcoran.com MAINTENANCE: $2,416 a month PROS: This approximately 3,000-square-foot loft in a six-story neo-Classical cast-iron building has a bright, sprawling
title: ON THE MARKET

body: A Brooklyn man who impersonated city workers to steal from elderly homeowners was sentenced yesterday to 16 years in prison, said Rose Gill Hearn, commissioner of the Department of Investigation. The man, Shawn M. Brown, 54, was convicted last month of burglary, criminal impersonation and other offenses after prosecutors charged that he claimed to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Impersonator Sentenced To Prison

body: Where the Old Times Roll Q. When I was a kid, there were game arcades on Broadway that featured Skee-Ball. Do any places in Manhattan still offer this game? My grandson (10) and I (70) love the game but can't find one place in Manhattan that offers it. A. Have no fear. You can find Skee-Ball in Lazer Park, an arcade at 163 West 46th Street, east of
title: F. Y. I.

body: Manhattan TRIBECA $1.45 million 39 Vestry Street (Hudson Street) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. condo in a prewar loft building; renovated kitchen, den, large living room, north exposure; common charge $606; taxes $5,448; listed at $1.495 million, 12 weeks on market (brokers: Tabak; Stribling & Associates) EAST VILLAGE $695,000 143 Avenue B
title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

body: The police are offering a $12,000 reward for information that leads to the arrest or conviction of the arsonist who started a fire that killed four people in Prospect Heights on Feb. 24. The fire, at 1033 Pacific Street, started when someone poured a flammable liquid on the building's stairwell and set it ablaze, authorities have said. Thick smoked
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Reward Offered In Fatal Fire

body: Prospect Heights Town House $1,650,000 BROOKLYN: 327 Park Place (near Underhill Avenue) A completely updated three-story, one-family 1890's house with four bedrooms and two and a half baths. The house has original details and is set on a lot that is 131 feet deep, with a landscaped garden. Diane Rayboy or Elisabeth Preis, Aguayo & Huebener (718)
title: ON THE MARKET

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: SOME things you find when you aren't looking. That's what happened to Kate Rope and David Allan. They had no success finding a rental bigger than the one they had, so they gave up. For the short term, their $1,400-a-month studio on St. Marks Place was adequate. It was their first marital home, and they were fond of it in many ways. They loved their
title: THE HUNT; Learning to Live in a (Slightly) Larger Space

body: It is, in a heartbreaking way, a variant on the classic immigrant story. Kassoum Fofana grew up in Bobo-Dioulasso, the second-largest city in the landlocked West African country of Burkina Faso. Mr. Fofana, a quick-witted and ambitious young man, was good with his hands and became a carpenter. He met a woman. Her name was Assita Coulibaly. A funny,
title: Fire Puts a Sad Ending on an Optimistic Immigrant Tale

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Iraqi Cities Under Curfew As Clerics Call for Restraint With the streets of Baghdad and other major cities largely emptied by a daytime curfew, imams across Iraq called for an end to the sectarian rioting that has left more than 170 people dead over three days, as political leaders held emergency meetings to contain the crisis.
title: News Summary

body: Theater 'STEAL AWAY: THE LIVING HISTORY OF HARRIET TUBMAN,' with puppets and actors, at the Workshop Theater, 312 West 36th Street, fourth floor, Manhattan. Saturdays at 11:30 a.m., through March 11. Tickets: $10; under 12, $8. Reservations: (212) 695-4173, ext. 5. 'What if ? The Rock Musical,' a retelling of Hans Christian Andersen's ''Little
title: Spare Times; For Children

body: To the Editor: In ''A Tragedy, but Not a Trend'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 29) Andrew White suggests that the ''horrific'' death of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown is an exception to the norm, saying the child welfare system has changed dramatically since 1995. In the 60's and 70's, caseworkers were mandated to visit welfare families every three months, regardless of
title: Child Welfare System: Has It Really Improved?

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: EVERYBODY knows where the Nets are going: Brooklyn. But where exactly are the Knicks going? There is no construction permit, no road map, no flight plan for these hapless vagabonds. The franchise with a present humiliated the franchise with a past last night in the Meadowlands, much worse than the 96-83 score indicates. The Knicks have now lost 7
title: Sports of The Times; While Nets Are Headed East, Knicks Are Going South

body: New York City's new teachers' contract took effect yesterday, causing wide disruption and confusion as most of the city's 1,400 schools changed schedules to adopt new tutoring sessions. The changes upended the routines of parents, educators, school bus companies and after-school programs. At Public School 16 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Isabel Cruz
title: New Tutoring Schedules in Schools Lead to Confusion

body: Of all the ways to get to Brooklyn, rowing a 24-foot boat across the Atlantic Ocean must be among the hardest. Especially when you have to build your own boat. And if you haven't actually practiced on the water since last summer. ''If I did that,'' said Victor Mooney, ''I wouldn't have had time to finish the boat.'' Finishing it has taken most of
title: A Slow, Solo Crossing of the Atlantic Is One Man's Response to the AIDS Crisis

body: IN the mid-1990's, Chris Piazza would walk the streets of Brooklyn looking for boarded-up carriage houses. ''I'd take down their addresses,'' she said, ''look up the tax records and write to the owners to see if they wanted to sell.'' She didn't hit pay dirt, so she and her husband at the time decided to move from Prospect Heights to Yonkers. It
title: HABITATS/Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; Her Carriage House Is a Stable for Her Art

body: ARTHUR DALLAS grew up in the Bronx, but left many years ago for the same reasons many others do. ''My wife and I decided to raise a family, and the school situation in the Bronx was impossible,'' said Mr. Dallas, a former police officer. They bought a home in Rye and put the kids through school. Even after a separation 15 years ago, he stayed in
title: Housing Prices Are Driving An Exodus

body: SUZANNE WHALEN grew up on Long Island, and she knows the script: Buy a house in the best school district you can afford and pay the price of extra stress, long hours at work and endless traffic until the children graduate. But because she had a telecommuting job, which meant she could live anywhere, Ms. Whalen and her husband, Andrew, rewrote the
title: House Costs Are Driving An Exodus

body: As the single parent of a 12-year-old girl, Rodney McEachern has a complaint easily understood by overburdened single parents everywhere. ''I need a vacation,'' he said recently with a sigh. He was scurrying between visitors in the living room and a dinner of turkey wings, Brussels sprouts and rice for his daughter, Mariah, on the stove of their
title: The Neediest Cases; An Ailing Father, and a Daughter Who Needs Extra Care for Emotional Disorders

body: TEN years ago, when the Narin family decided to move to Westchester, they might have been following a script. With children nearing school age, they sold their condominium in the Bronx and bought a house in Cortlandt Manor in search of better schools. Hundreds of thousands before them had beaten that well-worn path from the city to the suburbs, and
title: Now Even the Suburbs Are Getting Suburbs

body: FOUR years ago, if you had asked Stephen Joubert where he would be living in 2006, the last place he would probably have said was Florida. Mr. Joubert and his wife and three children were living in a small three-bedroom house in Edison, looking for something bigger and hoping to find a house in the $500,000 to $600,000 range, he said. As luck would
title: An Exodus Driven By Home Prices

body: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that he would undertake another sweeping reorganization of the school system bureaucracy, seeking to cut $200 million from central and regional administrative budgets and freeing at least 150 more schools from the oversight of superintendents provided they meet specific performance goals. The
title: Schools Chancellor to Give Principals More Autonomy

body: Each week, about 25,000 customers find their way by car, foot or public transportation to a five-month-old Home Depot store at 585 DeKalb Avenue, which sits on a five-acre site next to Public School 54, in a residential section of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. ''It's excitement all day long,'' said Ricky Campbell, the manager of the store, which
title: SQUARE FEET; Bringing a Big-Box Store to a Tough Area of Brooklyn

body: ARTHUR MELNICK shifted gears on his boxy white Nissan, skirted past Fulton Ferry Landing and described his vision for the future of Brooklyn. ''Look at this!'' he said, pointing at the nearly desolate ribbon of Furman Street. Traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway screamed overhead, and the old docks and industrial buildings along the East River
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Desire Named Streetcar
